pageProps.contentHtml:
harmonic functions

Let M∈RM \in \RM∈R, Ω⊆C\Omega \subseteq \CΩ⊆C be a bounded open set, and u ⁣:Ω→R\func{u}{\Omega}{\R}u:Ω→R be a harmonic function.

  1. Show that if

    lim sup⁡z→z0u(z)≤M(∗)\tag{$*$} \limsup_{z \to z_0} u\p{z} \leq Mz→z0​limsup​u(z)≤M(∗)

    for all z0∈∂Ωz_0 \in \partial\Omegaz0​∈∂Ω, then u(z)≤Mu\p{z} \leq Mu(z)≤M for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω.

  2. Show that if uuu is bounded from above and there exists a finite set F⊆∂ΩF \subseteq \partial\OmegaF⊆∂Ω such that (∗*∗) is valid for all z0∈∂Ω∖Fz_0 \in \partial\Omega \setminus Fz0​∈∂Ω∖F, then the conclusion of (1) is still true, i.e., it follows that u(z)≤Mu\p{z} \leq Mu(z)≤M for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω.
Solution.

  1. Let M′=sup⁡z∈Ωu(z)M' = \sup_{z \in \Omega} u\p{z}M′=supz∈Ω​u(z) and let {zk}k\set{z_k}_k{zk​}k​ be a sequence such that u(zk)→M′u\p{z_k} \to M'u(zk​)→M′. Since Ω\OmegaΩ is bounded, Ω‾\cl{\Omega}Ω is compact, so passing to a subsequence if necessary, we may assume without loss of generality that {zk}k\set{z_k}_k{zk​}k​ converges to some z0∈Ω‾z_0 \in \cl{\Omega}z0​∈Ω.

    If z0∈Ωz_0 \in \Omegaz0​∈Ω, then uuu attains its maximum u(z0)=M′u\p{z_0} = M'u(z0​)=M′ in Ω\OmegaΩ, so by the maximum principle, u≡M′u \equiv M'u≡M′ on the connected component containing z0z_0z0​. Furthermore, u≤Mu \leq Mu≤M, since if z∈∂Ωz \in \partial\Omegaz∈∂Ω, then M′=lim sup⁡w→zu(z)≤MM' = \limsup_{w \to z} u\p{z} \leq MM′=limsupw→z​u(z)≤M, so by definition of M′M'M′, u(z)≤M′≤Mu\p{z} \leq M' \leq Mu(z)≤M′≤M for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω.

    If z0∈∂Ωz_0 \in \partial\Omegaz0​∈∂Ω, then by definition,

    M′=lim⁡n→∞u(zn)≤lim sup⁡z→z0u(z)≤M,M' = \lim_{n\to\infty} u\p{z_n} \leq \limsup_{z \to z_0} u\p{z} \leq M,M′=n→∞lim​u(zn​)≤z→z0​limsup​u(z)≤M,

    and the claim follows since M′M'M′ was the supremum of uuu on Ω\OmegaΩ.

  2. Write F={p1,…,pn}F = \set{p_1, \ldots, p_n}F={p1​,…,pn​} and consider the function

    v(z)=∑k=1nlog⁡ ∣z−pkd∣,v\p{z} = \sum_{k=1}^n \log\,\abs{\frac{z - p_k}{d}},v(z)=k=1∑n​log∣∣​dz−pk​​∣∣​,

    where d=2sup⁡z,w∈Ω∣z−w∣<∞d = 2\sup_{z,w\in\Omega} \abs{z - w} < \inftyd=2supz,w∈Ω​∣z−w∣<∞, since Ω\OmegaΩ is bounded. In particular, ∣z−pk∣≤d2<d\abs{z - p_k} \leq \frac{d}{2} < d∣z−pk​∣≤2d​<d for all z∈Ω‾z \in \cl{\Omega}z∈Ω and 1≤k≤n1 \leq k \leq n1≤k≤n. Thus, v(z)v\p{z}v(z) is non-positive, and it is also a harmonic function on Ω\OmegaΩ: notice that f(z)≔∏k=1nz−pkdf\p{z} \coloneqq \prod_{k=1}^n \frac{z - p_k}{d}f(z):=∏k=1n​dz−pk​​ does not vanish on Ω\OmegaΩ, so it has a holomorphic logarithm ggg on all of Ω\OmegaΩ. Thus, v(z)=Re⁡g(z)v\p{z} = \Re{g\p{z}}v(z)=Reg(z), hence harmonic.

    Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 and consider φε=u+εv\phi_\epsilon = u + \epsilon vφε​=u+εv. Notice that as z→pkz \to p_kz→pk​, v(z)→−∞v\p{z} \to -\inftyv(z)→−∞. Thus, because uuu is bounded on Ω\OmegaΩ by, say, M′M'M′, we have φε≤M′+εv\phi_\epsilon \leq M' + \epsilon vφε​≤M′+εv. Thus,

    lim sup⁡z→pkφε(z)≤M′+lim sup⁡z→pkεv(z)=−∞≤M.\limsup_{z \to p_k} \phi_\epsilon\p{z} \leq M' + \limsup_{z \to p_k} \epsilon v\p{z} = -\infty \leq M.z→pk​limsup​φε​(z)≤M′+z→pk​limsup​εv(z)=−∞≤M.

    Moreover, since v≤0v \leq 0v≤0, we see that φε≤u\phi_\epsilon \leq uφε​≤u so in particular, lim sup⁡z→z0φε(z)≤M\limsup_{z \to z_0} \phi_\epsilon\p{z} \leq Mlimsupz→z0​​φε​(z)≤M for all z0∈∂Ω∖Fz_0 \in \partial\Omega \setminus Fz0​∈∂Ω∖F. In other words, φε\phi_\epsilonφε​ satisfies the hypotheses of (1) and so φε(z)=u(z)+εv(z)≤M\phi_\epsilon\p{z} = u\p{z} + \epsilon v\p{z} \leq Mφε​(z)=u(z)+εv(z)≤M for all z∈Ωz \in \Omegaz∈Ω. Letting ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, we get u(z)≤Mu\p{z} \leq Mu(z)≤M on Ω\OmegaΩ, which completes the proof.
